HUSSAM:\ Peace be upon you, too. BILAL:\ How are you, Hussam? Where are you calling from—your office or home? HUSSAM:\ I’m at the Oxfam office. My name’s Hussam Hassan. Let’s finish the introductions—then I’ll tell you why I reached out. HUSSAM:\ Sure. By the way, I’ve done quite a bit of training. RENAC Academy (the German renewable-energy institute) ran a “train-the-trainer” program in Iraq in 2023. They selected 20 people nationwide; I was one of them. After we passed the online modules and exams, our names were posted on the Solar Iraq platform—that’s where Nilam found my contact and reached me on WhatsApp. BILAL:\ That makes sense. Quick background on me: I’m Bilal, a curriculum-development consultant. I’ve been working across the Middle East since the Arab Spring—helping build creative spaces and skills programs. Right now I’m looking for trainers like you. Our goal in Mosul isn’t just to teach “green energy” theory; we want people to get jobs or launch businesses in solar. So we need a course that takes someone who already has some technical foundation—say an engineer or technician—and gives them the know-how and the business sense to earn a living in the sector. HUSSAM:\ Perfect—because I’m an electrical engineer myself. A while back I even tried to spin up a small solar start-up and work on a patent, then switched to an indoor vertical-farm idea. BILAL:\ Exactly the type of profile we need! Could you walk me through the trainings you currently deliver? What topics, what structure? Do you keep a syllabus? HUSSAM:\ RENAC gave us a full training package. I also volunteer as a business adviser with ITC’s SABi program. I’ve delivered short courses—four-day blocks, usually 9 a.m. – 1 p.m. The problem with such short courses is that trainees often get too much theory, too little hands-on. For solar you really need to let people wire, assemble, test. We sometimes take them to the Renewable-Energy Center near Baghdad University, but even that’s limited. BILAL:\ If you could design the ideal solar course that truly prepares people to start work straight after, what would it look like—duration, day-by-day focus? BILAL:\ Good. Everything you’re saying aligns with our draft schedule. What classroom techniques keep people engaged? HUSSAM:\ Peer teaching works well: give each student a small device—an irradiance meter, shadow meter, surge protector—let them research it for 15 minutes, then present on a flip-chart. HUSSAM:\ Exactly—on Day 5 give them a load profile and tell them: “Design the system, price it, choose components, justify it.” Then on Day 6 they present. BILAL:\ What are the biggest mistakes you see in the field? HUSSAM: 1. No cleaning – Panels get dusty, output drops, customers lose faith in solar. 2. Weak mounting – Cheap frames cannot handle wind; arrays shift or fall. 3. Wrong cables/breakers – Using AC hardware on DC lines is unsafe. We must drill maintenance and structural design into the course. BILAL:\ Agreed. How do we embed cleaning and wind-load lessons? HUSSAM:\ Show real-world examples—street-light panels that stopped working because no one washed them. Have trainees compare IV-curves of clean vs dirty panels. Build a business case for offering cleaning as a paid service. BILAL:\ Good point. Speaking of business: how do we blend technical and business training? HUSSAM: - Add a market-research field day—send trainees to interview 30 residents: generator costs, pain points, willingness to pay. - Teach basic bookkeeping and cash-flow—many small firms skip it. - Highlight after-sales services and warranties as a value proposition (rare in Iraq). BILAL:\ We’ll incorporate that. Final questions: can you recommend other trainers across Iraq, and how do we verify a trainee truly gained competence? HUSSAM: - I’ll share contacts from RENAC and other programs (Erbil, Basra, etc.). - For assessment: let private companies host two-month internships; we subsidize stipends. Companies get free help, trainees get practice. On our side, require each trainee to complete and upload a design report generated by a solar-design tool—becomes their portfolio. BILAL:\ Excellent. I’ll send you our draft Google Sheet; feel free to add comments or voice notes. I’ll be in Mosul mid-July—hope we can meet. HUSSAM:\ Looking forward to it.
